pycirk package¶

Submodules¶

pycirk.SUTops module¶

Created on Wed Nov 2 12:05:08 2016

Description: Class to perform SUT and IOT transformations and balancing

Scope: Modelling circular economy policies in EEIOA

@author:Franco Donati @institution:Leiden University CML

class pycirk.SUTops.SUTops[source]¶

Bases: object

Contains all basic operations to transform SUTs into IOTs and verify them It contains two subclasses defining two different trasformation methods PxP ITA Market share and Technical Coefficient methods note: It should be expanded to other transformation methods in the future

class IOT[source]¶

Bases: object

General IOT operations subclass some methods repeat from other subclasses but it’s good to have them divided for clarity

A(inv_diag_x)[source]¶

Technical coefficient matrix A = S * inv(diag(x))

B(diag_x)[source]¶

Primary input and intermediates extensions matrix

L()[source]¶

Leontief inverse L = (I-A)^-1

R(inv_diag_x)[source]¶

Primary input and intermediates extensions coefficient matrix

S(diag_x)[source]¶

Total product ouput S = A * diag_x

x(Y)[source]¶

total product output s the sum of Si and y

x_IAy(y)[source]¶

Total product ouput x = inv(I - A) * yi

class PxP_ITA_MSC[source]¶

Bases: object

Model with Market Share Coef. Prod x Prod Industry Technology assumption

A(D)[source]¶

Total requirement multipliers A = Z * D

B(diag_q)[source]¶

Extensions and primary input for IO tables

D(inv_diag_q)[source]¶

Market share coefficients D = V * inv(diag(q))

L()[source]¶

Leontief inverse L = (I-A)^-1

R(D, inv_diag_g)[source]¶

Input coefficients ext_matrix R = E * inv(diag(g))

S(D, diag_q)[source]¶

Intermediates S = Z * D * diag(q)

Z(inv_diag_g)[source]¶

Input requirements Z = U * inv(diag(g))

class PxP_ITA_TC[source]¶

Bases: object

Model with Transformation Coefficients ProdxProd Industry Technology assumption

B(diag_q)[source]¶

Extensions and primary input for IO tables

L(T, inv_diag_q)[source]¶

Input coefficients intermediates A = U * T * inv[diag (q)]

Multiplier matrix L = (I-A)^-1

R(T, inv_diag_q)[source]¶

Value added and extension requirement matrix R = E * inv(diag(g))

S(U)[source]¶

Intemediates S = U * T

T(inv_diag_g)[source]¶

Transformation matrix T = inv(diag(g)) * V

class difference[source]¶

Bases: object

This class is used to calculate the difference between scenarios

delta_Y(Yalt)[source]¶

method to calculate difference in Y Y = final demand baseline Yalt = final demand scenario

delta_x(Lalt, y)[source]¶

method to calculate difference in q L = Leontief of baseline Lalt = Leontief of scenario

class fdext[source]¶

Bases: object

RYB(YB)[source]¶

Method for transformation matrix of YB (e.g. final demand emissions) RB = YB * inv(diag(yj))

YB(diag_yj)[source]¶

Extensions and primary input for IO tables

inv()[source]¶

Returns inverse by dividing by 1 and eliminating inf and nan values

var(V, U, Y, E)[source]¶

Returns variables that are useful in all calculations

verifyIOT(Y, E)[source]¶

pycirk.apply_policy module¶

Created on Fri Nov 25 12:13:29 2016

Description: Reading policy values and modifying matrices for scenarios

Scope: Modelling the Circular Economy in EEIO

@author: Franco Donati @institution: Leiden University CML

class pycirk.apply_policy.Apply_policy(scen_file)[source]¶

Bases: object

Processes policy interventions and returns new matrices

apply_policy(scen_no, M, M_name)[source]¶

Separates policy interventions by matrix subject to intervention and aply policy interventions on specific matrix

scen_no = specific scenario e.g “1” or “scenario_1” M = matrix affected by the policies M_name = matrix name as diplayed under sheet_name[“matrix”]

basic_add(ide, a, at)[source]¶
basic_mult(ide, a, kt, kp)[source]¶

Policy intervention: It may be a primary intervention or an acillary action.

a = a supply chain or a point in it subject to policy kt = technical coefficient (max achievable technically) kp = penetration coefficient (level of market penet. of the policy)

copy(d, c, fx_kp)[source]¶

Moves the value from one or multiple cells (in the same row or column)

Substitution: Material subsitution or certain types of rebound effects

d = transaction to expand c = transaction subject to the direct policy intervention fx_kp = size of c that is added on the transaction to expand d

make_new(fltr_policies, M, M_name)[source]¶

Calculates and reassembles SUT or IOT matrices based on policy scenarios policy interventions

scenario = is the table with the policy intervations

M = matrix on which to implement the policies

x = columns (abscissa/horizontal) y = rows (ordinate/vertical)

*x.1 and *y.1 = coordinates for destination in substitution

policy_engine(M, inter, subs=False, copy=False)[source]¶

This function allows for the proccessing of the specified interventions onto a selected matrix. It calls various functions to modify the values in a specified matrix.

M = matrix of reference

inter = contains all specs for the intervention

y = index coordinate x = column coordinate ide = intervention identification number

kt = technical change coefficient kp = market penetration coefficient

fx_kp = market penetration coeffient applicable to substitution

expan = expansion coef. (used only for simple transaction changes)

substitution(d, s, fx_kp)[source]¶

Moves the value from one or multiple cells (in the same row or column)

Substitution: Material subsitution or certain types of rebound effects

If the size of the array of the original value is different from that of the destination (substituted), we obtain the total of the value to be substituted and the substitution is implemented by dividing the tot by the number of elements on the destination array and then added to the destination array (equally distributed)

d = transaction with which we are substituting s = transaction that was subject to the direct policy intervention fx_kp = size of c that is added on the transaction to expand d

pycirk.make_secondary_flows module¶

Created on Mon Jul 16 15:10:19 2018 Description: Modifying SUT to ensure appearance of secondary material flows in IOT

Scope: Modelling the Circular Economy in EEIO

@author:Franco Donati @institution:Leiden University CML

pycirk.make_secondary_flows.allocate_sec_mat(V, U, Y, prod_or, ind_or)[source]¶

This function allows to move the primary material output from the secondary material industries to the secondary material output. This allows for the presence of secondary materials in the IOT once they are transformed from SUTS.

prod_or = row position of the primary supplied material ind_or = colum pos. of the primary industry supplying primary material

pycirk.make_secondary_flows.make_secondary(data)[source]¶

This allows to allign secondary flow in such a way that they then appear in the IOT

pycirk.pycirk module¶

Created on Tue Nov 15 16:29:23 2016

Description: Outputting scenarios

Scope: Modelling the Circular Economy in EEIO

@author:Franco Donati @institution:Leiden University CML

class pycirk.pycirk.Start(method=0, directory='', aggregation='bi-regional', file=None, make_secondary=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

directory = directory in which you want to work and save

method = 0 >> Prod X Prod Ind-Tech Assumption Technical Coeff method method = 1 >> Prod X Prod Ind-Tech Assumption Market Share Coeff method

aggregation = “bi-regional” (EU- ROW) or None (multi-regional 49 regions)

From start you can launch all the analysis specifications listed under scenarios.xls

All directories and base data are specified in dirs.py

Results will be saved in the output folder

The programme only considers two regions EU and Rest-Of-World (ROW)

Permitted SUT transformation Methods are

method = 0 >> Prod X Prod Ind-Tech Assumption Technical Coeff method method = 1 >> Prod X Prod Ind-Tech Assumption Market Share Coeff method

results_only = True >> output only results (spec’d in scenarios.xls) results_only = False >> output all IOTs and results

scen_no = 0 - n (0 = baseline)
n = is number of scenarios specified by sheet in scenarios.xls “scenario_1” is also allowed for scenarios None, 0, base and baseline are also accepted for baseline
all_results()[source]¶

Output all results in a table

plot_results(results)[source]¶

Plots bar graph of the summary results

run_one_scenario(scen_no, results_only=True)[source]¶

Run to check specific scenario

results_only = False, True
  • True, output results for analysis
  • False, output all tables plus results for analysis
save_all_scenarios()[source]¶

Save all results in separate files and sheets data e.g. all_results.all_tables

save_everything()[source]¶

Save all scenarios and results

save_one_scenario(scen_no, results_only=False)[source]¶

Output all results in a table

save_results()[source]¶

Save results

data = any IOT table spec_row = row in the scenarios sheet specifying settings scen_no = name of the scenario
